restrictions: The Artists agree that the Artwork, including the Artwork as it appears during the installation process, may be photographed and/or filmed in any format by Princeton University and individuals authorized by the University for use by Princeton University for the purposes of installation and object documentation. Artists grant to Princeton University for as long as it owns the Artwork a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to photograph, and license others to photograph, the Artwork in its entirety, but not in part unless from pre-approved photographs, and reproduce such photographs (i) for non-commercial purposes such as catalogues, brochures about the Artwork, educational materials, press releases, signage, and use on Princeton University Websites and publications or any other literature of Princeton University describing its campus (ii) for non-commercial purposes such as brochures, programs and press releases to promote Princeton University.  Any filming of the Artwork that is more than fleeting and incidental must be approved by the Artists.  For avoidance of doubt, non-commercial purposes under this paragraph means the articles are not for sale.  Further, no merchandising rights are herein granted under any condition.  Such license is conditioned on Princeton University’s use of the credit described below, unless the use of the Artwork is an incidental use.

makers.displaymaker: Doug and Mike Starn, American, born 1961

texts.textentryhtml: This monumental glass, steel, and bronze sculpture by identical twin brothers Doug and Mike Starn is a continuation of their exploration of organic systems through root and branch forms and a direct response to the arboretum-like character of the Princeton campus. The extraordinary colors of the glass inside the 18-foot-tall frames are created by a new glass-dying technique pioneered in Germany.
Commissioned by the Princeton University Art Museum, 2015.
